Award.AwardTitle: WiFiUS: Collaborative Research: Data-Guided Resource Management for Dense Heterogeneous Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The emerging paradigm of dense heterogeneous wireless networks (HetNet), while essential to meeting the explosive growth of wireless traffic, poses unseen challenges to classical cellular network design principles. In traditional cellular systems, spectrum and resource management are often based on the assumption of static and regular topology/traffic patterns. Further, each cell operates with an orthogonal set of resources and requires little inter-cell coordination. However, such traditional approaches are out-dated and inefficient in dense HetNets:the proliferation of small-size cells makes the network topology and traffic characteristics highly irregular and varying; and tighter coordination across cells becomes a necessity when users traverse many small-cells frequently. Thus, there is an acute need to re-examine fundamental ways to design HetNets that can (i) quickly adapt to irregular topology and changing load patterns, and (ii) manage cell coordination at scale with minimal overhead to achieve robust and dependable application-level performance.

To address this open challenge, this WiFiUS project develops new framework, architecture and algorithms for adaptive, efficient, and dependable spectrum management and resource allocation in dense heterogeneous cellular networks. First, the project team develops a new hypercell architecture that views a macro-cell and the overlapping small-cells as a single logical entity. This new architecture allows hypercells to acquire a global view of the load/channel/mobility/application patterns across multiple base-cells, thereby enabling more effective and dynamic multi-cell coordination at scale. Furthermore, the team develops a data-guided operational framework that exploits both provider-collected and user-contributed data to address the inherent complexity of dynamic multi-cell coordination. Based on historical data, this approach migrates higher-complexity computations to offline, and thus achieves high spectrum efficiency and user QoE with low-overhead. The US/Finland team brings together a wide range of wireless expertise from physical layer design to network resource management. Having a successful collaboration record, the team carries out joint research activities in the following three aspects: 1) data collection and traffic pattern identification; 2) data-guided spectrum management and base-station cooperation; and 3) hypercell link adaptation, measurement, and resource management.

The success of the project has a broad impact on the wireless communications industry by addressing multiple timely and critical challenges that arise from the exponential growth of cellular traffic. The project outcomes will also provide important insights into big-data mining and learning for cellular resource management. The results from this work will be widely disseminated through journal/conference publications, and be incorporated into undergraduate and graduate education endeavors.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The emerging paradigm of dense heterogeneous networks (HetNet), while essential to meeting the explosive growth of wireless traffic, poses great challenges to classical cellular design principles. In traditional cellular systems, spectrum management and resource allocation are often based on static and regular topology/traffic patterns. Further, each cell operates with orthogonal resources and performs minimal inter-cell coordination except for handoffs. However, such traditional approaches are difficult and inefficient in dense small-cell deployments, where the network topology and traffic patterns become highly irregular and cell boundaries become blurred. Thus, there is an acute need to understand fundamental ways to design HetNets that can (i) quickly adapt to irregular topology and changing load patterns, and (ii) manage cell coordination at scale with minimal overhead to achieve robust and dependable application-level performance.

To address such challenges, in the project, we have investigated a plethora of heterogeneous networking scenarios with dynamic wireless traffic, leveraging traffic pattern, user experience data, and channel signaling information. We have developed efficient mechanisms that utilize traffic load and topology information to adaptively form virtual base-stations based on the principle of Gibbs sampling. We have studied how to leverage data for fast and adaptive mall-cell scenario resource allocation and developed adaptive clustering algorithms. We have studied data-guided resource management schemes in cellular networks with the specific goal of reducing the number of customer complaints at operators and developed a closed-loop approach. We further have investigated the design of distributed small cell base-station power control mechanisms for cross-tier interference mitigation in downlink using existing feedback signals such as CQI and ACK/NAK. We have investigated effective spectrum sharing for coexisting Wi-Fi and LTE-U services based on a novel concept of hyper access point (HAP). We have studied how to improve the spectrum efficiency of the unlicensed or D2D users with minimum disturbance to the incumbent WiFi users in the presence of LTE-U access or cellular connections under D2D. We have investigated the optimization of joint user association and resource allocation to further improve system throughput and user fairness.  We have also studied the deployment of mixed-mode D2D communication user equipment in which users can operate in multiple modes of D2D or cellular through resource multiplexing. Within this framework, we have studied the problem of maximizing weighted D2D sum rate under cellular rate constraints by optimizing mixed mode allocation and resource allocation in term of transmit power and subchannel assignment. In joint collaboration with our partners in Finland, we have used opportunistic scheduling to exploit the multiuser diversity to improve the performance of wireless communications based on channel feedback sent from the receiver. 

The outcome of the project also includes 14 peer-reviewed conference publications and 11 journal publications. The project also facilitated the education of eight graduate students and one postdoc researcher. Furthermore, the project strengthened the collaboration among three universities in two countries. Our research results have been widely disseminated through conferences, seminars, and meetings with industrial collaborators.
